title: It feels like Riot and the community have very different ideas of "unfair" mechanics.
body:
A lot of times when riot nerfs something that doesn't seem to be readily apparent as OP they say things like "hidden power", these like, hit a button and you're better abilities like {{champion:19}} W, which got nerfed by almost half it's duration, {{champion:44}}'s W aura and team wide steroid on ult (both also nerfed a while back), etc. skills with low interactivity whose effects may not be readily apparent to the untrained eye. 



But whenever I see people complaining about a mechanic on the boards or elsewhere, it's not "hidden power" it's power that is inherently low on counterplay. 
% max HP true damage on {{champion:67}} for just auto attacking
Long or frequent periods of untargetable via the pool of tears and troll poll on {{champion:8}} and {{champion:105}} 
Or mobility that still has very little direct counter other than "pick someone with mobility too", you can use your mobility to be gone long before {{champion:44}} stun hits you due to low missile speed or dodge all the CC that's been reworked into skillshots.



The things the community finds to be unbalanced are things that are apparent and clear on what is happening, and it FEELS skillful to use, but when you're on the other end of it, there's very little you can actually do. % max HP true damage can't be itemized against, except for attack speed slows on the armor items that do nothing to mitigate the true damage's actual damage. The troll poll and such are effected by what, DoTs applied before using the skill and tethers applied before activation? The only counters to all the mobility are toxic in their own right and complained about too, such as {{champion:1}}'s stun Tibbers with no warning, {{champion:13}}'s perma root, etc. Other than these, the answer is usually "just CC them before they can do anything" which would be fine if these kinds of issues weren't so common, you don't have the CC every game to keep 3 or 4 of the 5 opposing team from moving while you 100-0 them, that happens once in a blue moon.



This has led to patch after patch of things being nerfed that didn't seem like all that big of deals, while idea after idea is pitched to deal with the problems players want to see fixed and see nothing in return. I've seen untargetable can get hit by AOE moves. I've seen make all CC work like Veigars new cage where the second you get CCed you drop dead in your tracks, even if mid dash. I've seen the idea of a CC specifically to stop mobility, cripple. 
I'm thankful that there's been a burst of feedback from Riot, so I felt like now was the time to make this post, since it doesn't seem like it'll just fall on deaf ears.

I'm actually not sure our definitions of unfair are all that different, because a lot of the stuff you described as unfair _is_ unfair when considered in isolation. Champions should be allowed to do unfair individual things if they are exciting and fun so long as the full package they're bringing to the game is not unfair. Vlad pool is unfair on its own, but its cooldown and cost are intended to come at some consequence to him when he uses it.

The examples of Warwick W and Taric W aren't so much unfair as they're just not satisfying for how much power they're actually giving, so more often than not it can be good to emphasize the power of champion kits in areas that are more appreciable.

This may not be how everyone feels, and please do correct me if I'm alone, but when I'm playing a champion, I (as a player) don't want to be fair. I want to _feel_ powerful and cheap as all hell but actually _be_ balanced.

I actually think the difference largely comes down to the fact that:

(1) many players are frustrated by kits which become oppressive when ahead, while
(2) Riot seems more concerned with kits which provide lots of power in an otherwise even game.

Fizz, Vayne, Annie, Vlad, etc. are all totally fine if they aren't ahead, but once they get a lead and begin to snowball, they are oppressive and it feels massively unfun to play against them.  Riot is totally okay with the concept of snowball champions.  The reality is that some champions snowball incredibly easily with a lead, while others are only slightly stronger when ahead.

On the other hand, some champions have abilities that are incredibly strong even when even or down in gold.  These abilities frequently offer hidden power that may completely determine an otherwise even game.  Taric's armor aura or Warwick's ability to single handedly neuter an enemy carry are both abilities that don't require many resources to be incredibly effective.  These are the abilities Riot seems to be more concerned about.  In reality, these probably are the type of abilities that have a bigger impact on more games, as champs with these abilities frequently do tend to have a higher win rate than champs with great snowball ability, but these champions generally don't feel oppressive in the same way that a fed Annie does.

All of that being said, I personally think there is still something wrong with champions that feel too oppressive when ahead.  The reality is that most of League's player base isn't playing in high level play where deaths are less frequent, and it is very common for snowball champions to start snowballing.  When a snowball champion gets fed off one bad enemy laner, the power fantasy of these snowball champions has a significant negative impact on the play experience of every other player on that enemy team.  In my opinion, this is what breeds lots of toxicity.  When the enemy Annie or Fizz gets a couple of solo kills early on your mid laner, there isn't really any light at the end of the tunnel in most games.  

Champions who are very oppressive when ahead create a culture of blame which undermines team play.  Rather than try to figure out how to win, because it seems hopeless, many teams instead resort to calling out a player for having "fed" the oppressive champion.  This obviously breeds toxicity.

Further, however, champions who are very oppressive when ahead also sometimes have a negative impact on the players who play them.  The power fantasy of these champions frequently devolves into being able to walk around the map with impunity and kill anyone they encounter, even 1v2ing or 1v3ing at times.  Players who experience this power fantasy, or players who watch it spin out, or who are forced to try to deal with it, frequently draw the wrong conclusions and mistakenly view this as core to the league experience.  These experiences are what spawn the "carry" mentality, where players start to believe they have to single handedly carry games or else they are going to lose.  This leads players to start to feel that if an enemy player is snowballing, the game is over, and they stop playing.  Some players take it further and begin to feel like if they give up even a slight lead, they aren't going to be able to carry, and thus aren't going to be able to win.

I think _fair_ is a subjective view, to be honest. I can think of a series of examples that would feel unfair in comparison to the ones mentioned in the original post, but that may be just my point of view. For one, I've never had issues with Vladimir's pool, since like you mentioned, it has a hefty cost for using it, along with a sharp cooldown. Even Annie's combo doesn't bother me, and I typically main characters that can easily be destroyed in a blink of an eye. I do hate the sheer carry potential Vayne has, but that's her character by nature.

Thing is though...the only real issue that doesn't feel "fair" at all is Fizz. Sure, his escape is also a nuke/slow, but the cost gets outweighed by the sheer power it offers on such a short cooldown. Sure he offers high levels of fun for the player, but his opponent deals with a VERY high level of frustration at any point beyond lvl 5. His kit as a whole feels detrimental to the feeling of the game, at least in my eyes. Question is, how could you fix that without gutting him?

Personally I prefer the opposite. I want to feel like I outplayed the opponent not because I pressed my buttons in the right order to delete them, nor because I put them in a lose-lose situation with one of my abilities, but because I could predict his moves and outplay them with that knowledge. It's the difference between waiting in a bush waiting for your opponent to blow an ability to CS faster allowing you to go in on them, and waiting in a bush because you know you can go in on them when they go near the minion wave regardless of their CDs.

Most balance changes and reworks recently have been really good about this, but a few of the latest champion releases not so much (looking at you, Kalista!).

I don't feel that logic was applied to Veigar's gutting, since his stun had many built in counters and was his only means to land dark matter or self peel. That alone was what broke him, but the ultimate nerf and the Q rework just removed the reward for skillful play from Veigar, replacing it with 100% reliability on the enemy tripping up.

Just to ask: What were the built in counters to Veigar's cage? People like to say items like Banshee's don't get to count, because that's counter-building, not counter-play. So, removing an item that blocks an unforeseen spell, what counter was there to a Veigar within about 1000 range just dropping a stun on you much more frequently than Annie's Tibbers and for much longer duration? There was no reliable action the enemy could take against his stun. It was pretty absurd if you actually remember being on the receiving end of it as well, especially from a support Veigar who only had to use it to peel or just CC a vital target, without having to worry so much about how he'd get to the target himself. 

The ult nerf is uniformly bad, though, that's because nerfs are bad things, usually. The Q rework though.. doesn't that now reward him even more for skillful play? It allows you to potentially kill 2 minions per Q, which isn't too likely, I understand, or kill a minion while harassing the enemy champion at the same time, which is much more likely than the boards have led me to believe. That sounds more rewarding for skill than a point-and-click "+1 AP or harass" to me.

What skillful play was there to be seen from someone who only had 1 hard to land ability, which could be made negligibly easy to land by landing a fairly easy stun (gonna be honest: I barely even played Veigar but still had a very high chance of landing that stun by making sure the edge was on the champion, it was incredibly easy), paired with 2 point-and-click abilities? That sounds like the type of kit that most people complain about, to be honest.

So I guess that brings me to another question: Was he actually fine or are people wanting to say he was fine because they want what they once had unchanged? Was he actually healthy or are people just saying he was because of how much power budget was in his stun therefore it deserved to feel like it was broken?

While I agree on the general point you are making, I disagree with your examples where you talk about Vlad and Fizz.

You talk about Vlad's pool and Fizz's trollpole both being really unfair abilities, but they are actually counterexamples of each other.
Vlad is a champion with relatively low burst but high sustained damage, who is meant to survive for a long time during fights, continuing to deal damage.  Because of that, his pool allows hit to maybe get an extra two spells off during a fight where he might otherwise be killed, or maybe allows him to dodge some high-impact spells or escape a gank.  On the other hand, this skill has a huge cost to Vlad - 20% of his health and a massive cooldown.

Meanwhile, Fizz in a champion who can instantly kill you if you get close to him.  He has massive amounts of burst damage.  His trollpole has a much, much shorter cooldown and merely a mana cost to use, which means that he can deal massive burst damage and then become untargetable to avoid any repercussions for his risk move; he also gets to wait for his cooldowns in safety, and his individual skills are much more impactful than Vlad's once he gets them back up.

With some CDR and mana regen, Fizz pays almost nothing for this skill, so he is able to use it much more freely to dodge less-important spells.  It's also much more versatile because it allows him to reposition and deals massive damage to anyone nearby when he comes down.  Enemies are *punished* for waiting for him to leave his untargeable state because of the AoE damage.  Compare this to Vlad, who only gains a slight movement speed boost and whose pool does relatively little damage.  Enemies can easily wait for him to come out of his pool and then murder him afterwards.


In my opinion, Vlad is an example of how to do untargetability properly - a long-cooldown high-cost ability that allows Vlad to avoid a few seconds of pain, and survive a little longer in fights to deal a little more damage, placed alongside a kit of slow, sustained damage and immobility.

Meanwhile, Fizz is an example of the wrong way to do untargetability - a short-cooldown low-cost ability that can be used to dodge almost anything, which also deals heavy damage, allows Fizz to choose if he wants to re-enage or not, and is coupled with a kit of extreme burst damage.
